Every knife is a one of a kind masterpiece; no two knives are the same and each is individually numbered.

This particular knife is Custom Fixed Blade 048. It is made from O1 high carbon tool steel, and has a cold blue stonewashed finish.  The handles are burnished copper, and are overlayed with black linen micarta.  The holes in the handle are lined with nickel silver tubes. The blade is RAZOR sharp, and the tool steel has excellent edge retention while still being easy to sharpen, making this an extremely beautiful and extremely practical knife.

I will be selling this gorgeous blade for $350 or best offer. I am also open to trade for AR-15 parts plus cash. The price is firm and non-negotiable, this knife is worth every penny and I like it enough to keep it if the price isn't met. The knife comes with two sheaths. Overall Length: 8 and 3/4"

title: For Sale:  VIS Radom Model 35 9mm Grade I/II. All matching S/N's
postcontent:
Vis Radom Model 35 9mm, Grade I possibly II. Great condition.
This one is truly a jewel and fine momento from history.The Radom is widely considered to be one of the finest handguns ever made, and ahead of its time sharing only the look of a 1911.  My grandfather took this from a German officer in Battle of the Bulge (so my father tells me.) He brought it back and had it Nickel plated (oops.) The later grades of Radoms were known for inferior finish, however, I beleive my grandfather refinished it because he had access to the plating shop and he loved things that were chrome or shiny (cars, jewlry, etc.)
This has the shoulder stock slot and all the levers. That tells me it is at least a Grade II. There is no Letter(alpha) prefix to the serial number, which hints that it was one of the very first german issues. Germans used alpha prefixes. Also, it was common for the later grades to have mis-matched S/N's. This one has ALL MATCHING S/N's. There are several german proof stamps as well as SS and Maltese cross stamps. 
I beleive this could be a pre-invasion polish made unit which was later simply stamped and issued by the germans. 
I have quite a few pics but can only upload a couple here. If you are interested I can certainly send more pics and try to answer any questions. 

Location: Choctaw, OK
Phone: REDACTED Call before 8PM please.
No trades. Cash only please.
Thanks for viewing.

postcontent:
Beautiful, brand new, and never used custom fixed blade by Todd Szczechowski at Stonewood Designs. Todd makes every knife completely by hand using only the finest techniques and materials. Every knife is a one of a kind masterpiece; no two knives are the same and each is individually numbered.

This particular knife is Custom Fixed Blade 048. It is made from O1 high carbon tool steel, and has a cold blue stonewashed finish. The handles are burnished copper, and are overlayed with black linen micarta. The holes in the handle are lined with nickel silver tubes. The blade is RAZOR sharp, and the tool steel has excellent edge retention while still being easy to sharpen, making this an extremely beautiful and extremely practical knife.

I will be selling this gorgeous blade for $350 or best offer. I am also open to trade for AR-15 parts plus cash. The price is firm and non-negotiable, this knife is worth every penny and I like it enough to keep it if the price isn't met. The knife comes with two sheaths. The first is a tight fitting, custom molded Kydex sheath that is equipped with a Mini Tek-lok. The second is a custom leather sheath, also hand-made by Todd Szczechowski. The knife's exact measurements are as follows:

Overall Length: 8 and 3/4"
Blade Thickness: 1/8"
Cutting Edge: 4"
Blade Depth: 3/4"
Hardness: 59-60 HRC

NOTE: A thin film of oil should be applied to this blade every once in a while to prevent corrosion.

Less than 1" thick, 6" overall length and weighing just 19 oz., the Shield is perfect for concealed carry or a law-enforcement backup gun. Striker fired with a low bore axis and an 18¬∞ grip angle, the Shield delivers a natural sight picture and points instinctively. The consistent trigger pull and short trigger reset enhance accuracy and make for fast follow-up shots. This is the very same stock the USMC uses on its M40 series sniper rifles.  The stock has a height-adjustable comb and is adjustable for length of pull via spacers.  The rifle is also equipped with a Badger Ordnance 20 MOA scope base.  The stock has been glass-bedded with Marine Tex.

I have not fired this rifle.  I have only removed it from the box to function test it.  The rifle comes in the original box with the manual, gun lock, the factory test target showing a 3-shot group of 0.64" at 100 yards, and the factory logbook which details the only 8 rounds that have ever been fired through this rifle (at the factory).  If you've been planning on building something like a Rem 700 for long range shooting, consider this rifle as a pre-built, tried and true alternative.

In addition to its high quality components from well-known manufacturers, this rifle comes with a lifetime service policy from FN.  If you are interested or have any more questions, feel free to email me.  I have added a stock photo as I only have a crappy camera phone, but you're more than welcome to read what people have to say about these rifles here:

http://www.snipershide.com/forum/ubbthreads.php?ubb=showflat&Number=2540582#Post2540582

Note that my price on this rifle is FIRM.  I purchased the rifle for almost $1600, and I'm selling it in the same condition I received it in.  If you are familiar with TAC-CORD on Sniper's Hide or ARFCOM, this is one of the very rifles you will receive from him, but for a couple hundred dollars less.

Edit:  Added a photo of the rifle.

title: For Sale:  Nazi Stamped German Walther P-38 circa 1943-44
postcontent: I am looking to sell this Walther P-38 which was a Christmas gift when I was a teenager.  It was purchased from a friend of my parents whose father brought it back from Germany after WWII. Aside from occasional firings it has been kept in it's hard shell holster in a lock box. According to the serial number it was made in late 1943 or 1944. The gun is marked on both the left and right sides with the Nazi 359 stamp. The serial number is 192 d ac 44. The only issue with the gun is that it needs a firing pin cover which came off the last time it was fired. The absence of this part does not prevent the gun from firing and the part sells on various sites for no more than $30. It is a sweet shooting gun that is deadly accurate. It's even more accurate than my Luger. The price includes the hard shell holster and two clips. I have lots of detailed pictures of the gun that I can send you if you want a closer look at it.
